Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency today announced settlements with two companies selling agricultural chemicals in Arizona and California over improper storage and containment of federally regulated pesticides.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/90f2623201eb56e585257c4600682b61.html

Description: On or about May 22, 2013, Helena Chemical Corporation (Helena") at a terminal located in Welch, Oklahoma, knowingly and willfully disposed of restricted use chemicals including, Atrazine and S-Metolachor, which are two of the main active ingredients in Medal II AT, a restricted use pesticide, in a manner inconsistent with the labeling for Medal II AT. Defendant was sentenced 36 months of probation, and to pay $150,000 Federal fine and $75,000 restitution.
Info Source: http://cfpub.epa.gov/compliance/criminal_prosecution/index.cfm?action=3&prosecution_summary_id=2700&searchParams=M5%2C%3A%2FXT%2A%5CCYZ%40O%3B%20W_%2AYN5%5E%3EK99%2A%29W%3CU%3FV%23DH%5BZ8%227TRPH%3BJQH%229%3FD%3C%26Z%40CY%26%0AM7EFH%21%25%21%3A%23%3DV%40%3A%2A_%3AB8%2A%5DR%3BB%25%5E9%5B2D%22I2K565NEY7M%21-U%40%2B8%22J%29Y%23%24LNJ%40DX%24%0A%2F5YJ%3EP%27O_K04_G%5C%3E%290M8%28%0A

https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L01493#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 424690: Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Marubeni Corporation, a Japanese trading company, was sentenced for its participation in a scheme to pay bribes to high-ranking government officials in Indonesia to secure a lucrative power project.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/marubeni-corporation-sentenced-foreign-bribery-violations

Description: Marubeni Corporation agreed to pay a $54.6 million criminal penalty to resolve charges related to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act for its alleged participation in a decade-long scheme to bribe Nigerian government officials to obtain engineering, procurement and construction contracts.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/marubeni-corporation-resolves-foreign-corrupt-practices-act-investigation-and-agrees-pay-546
http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr7140-15

Description: Gavilon Grain agreed to pay a $7,886 civil penalty and fund a Supplemental Environmental Project with an estimated cost of $866,646 in settlement of allegations it violated its emission permits by failing to apply oil to all grain received, exceeding the permitted amount of grain received by hopper truck, failing to monitor the amount of grain from straight truck deliveries, failing to keep records of truck deliveries, and failing to submit applications to modify a permit prior to construction and operation. The SEP provided credit to settle the remaining civil penalty of $172,870.
Info Source: https://cloud.env.state.nm.us/air/?c=358&k=91ab30fe46
